newsitem.title: UK: Britain the place to develop gene-modified crops.
newsitem.headline: Britain the place to develop gene-modified crops.

text.p: Britain, with its large professional growers operating in a small geographic area, is an ideal country to develop genetically modified crops, managing director of United Oilseeds, Martin Farrow said.
Speaking at a recent industry conference Cereals'97, Farrow said that Britain has the advantage of being a small country with good logistics.
"Before long we shall see a new range of exciting crops coming onto UK farms," Farrow said.
But initially new crops will need to be grown separately, stored separately, brought together without fear of mixing, and processed separately.

"Britain has been doing that for years with hi-erucic oilseed rape. It is a logistics excercise and being a small island with proficient growers and good infrastructure we can do it well," Farrow said.
But Farrow warned of added costs for farmers keeping crops separate and for organisations such as United Oilsees in collection, aggregation, storage and seed processing.
"These are costs that will have to be met from the consumer," he said.
